bibl.title: Letter from A.N. Tasker to Howard A. Kelly, October 24, 1922

div1.p: Tasker relates a conversation with Emilie Lawrence Reed. He provides information on Clara Maass, and gives permission to use a photograph of a portrait of George M. Sternberg.

div1.head: Letter from A.N. Tasker to Howard A. Kelly, October 24, 1922
div1.opener:
IN REPLY REFER TO S.G.O.----------------------------------------------
ANT-VTB
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
October 24, 1922.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1406 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
My dear Dr. Kelly:
div1.p:
Referring again to your letter of October 13th,
Mrs. Reed has just now called me by telephone. She knew
nothing of the case of Miss Clara Louise Maass (the name
of the nurse concerning whom you asked), but from the
office of the Superintendent of the Army Nurse Corps in
the Surgeon General's Office, I learned that Miss Maass
died in August, 1901, of yellow fever following the bite
of an infected mosquito to which she had voluntarily sub-
mitted. The purpose of this voluntary action is not def-
initely known but it is thought that her hope was to become
immune through suffering a mild attack of the disease as the
result of being bitten by an old mosquito that had not for
several weeks or months been permitted to bite yellow fever
patients. However, so far as concerns the purposes of her
action there is nothing more available than surmise. She
had been an army nurse, but her contract had been annulled
on May 7, 1900. Whether she had remained continuously in
Havana following her separation from the service or whether
she had visited the United States and then returned to Ha-
vana cannot be with certainty established. At any rate the
Superintendent of the Army Nurse Corps was quite sure that
immediately previous to her death she had been doing private
nursing or other professional work among Army and Navy people
stationed in Cuba.

Mrs. Reed knows nothing of any monument ever having
been erected to Major Reed's memory either in Havana or Panama.
General Noble is quite sure that no such monument has ever ap-
peared in Panama and he suggests that Dr. Agramonte, now Minister
of Health for Cuba, might give you definite information as to
what has or has not been done in Havana.

Mrs. Reed asked me to convey to you her very kindest
regards. She also asked me to invite your attention to the fact
that Congress has recently increased the pension granted Mrs. Gorgas,
but that no similar action has ever been taken in her case. She
expressed herself as believing this to be an unjust discrimination.
I promised her to transmit both of these messages to you.

We have here in the Library what I consider to be
a very excellent portrait of General Sternberg. Personally
I think it is as good a one as I have ever seen, though
there is always of course the possible question of taste.
I believe our portrait would make a very excellent illustra-
tion for the chapter in your book on General Sternberg.
Should you so desire, Mr. Reeves of the Army Medical Museum,
an accomplished photographer, will be glad to prepare for
you a reproduction at the usual rates.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, A. N. Tasker
Major, Medical Corps, U.S.Army FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
